name: Dev Task Queue
description: Create and run an agent-ready development queue from issues/PRs with progress checkpoints.
prompt:
Developer task queue workflow.

Goal
- Turn incoming engineering work into a prioritized queue that agents can execute with visible progress.

Inputs
- Repository: {{repository}}
- Scope filter: {{scope_filter}}
- Max parallel tasks: {{max_parallel_tasks}}
- Progress delivery channel: {{progress_channel}}

Steps
1) Pull candidate work items for repo "{{repository}}" (issues/PR comments/backlog tasks) using available GitHub/MCP tools.
2) Filter by "{{scope_filter}}" and estimate complexity/risk.
3) Build a queue with:
   - Priority order
   - Suggested owner (agent/human)
   - Acceptance criteria
   - Dependency notes
4) Start execution batches with at most {{max_parallel_tasks}} active tasks.
5) For each task, post progress checkpoints and blockers to "{{progress_channel}}" when possible.
6) For code changes, summarize diffs and STOP before merge/deploy unless explicitly approved.
7) Output queue state snapshot and next recommended batch.

Rules
- Never merge, deploy, or close issues without explicit confirmation.
- Keep status updates concise and verifiable.
- If integrations are missing, provide setup steps and continue with a local plan.

parameters.name: progress_channel
parameters.description: Where progress updates should be formatted for

routing.useWhen: Use when the user asks to queue software tasks for agent execution with progress updates and safe merge/deploy gating.
routing.dontUseWhen: Do not use when the request is asking for planning documents, high-level strategy, or non-executable discussion; use the relevant planning or design workflow instead.
routing.outputs: Outcome from Dev Task Queue: prioritized queue, execution status, and explicit approval checkpoints.
routing.successCriteria: Builds a practical task queue with visible progress and no unsafe autonomous merge/deploy actions.
